context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: America On Opioids: The Many Faces Of The Country's Addiction Crisis
context_meta.summary: During HuffPost’s Listen to America tour at the end of 2017, reporters encountered stories ― some heartbreaking, some triumphant ― of opioids and their effects. The fearsome impact of this public health crisis weighed heavily on people’s minds in every town HuffPost’s bus visited. “This crisis has been brewing for a long time,” said Nancy Campbell, a professor at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, New York, who has published several books on drug policy and treatment.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Hittin' The Big Easy: HuffPost’s Listen To America Tour Stops In New Orleans
context_meta.summary: New Orleans holds such an illustrious place in the history of the United States, including the waves of refugees who have called the city home and the battles that have been waged there. In recent years, New Orleans was in the public eye because of the damage it experienced during Hurricane Katrina. Since then, New Orleans has steadily rebuilt and flourished once more. Its annual Mardi Gras parties and its jazz festival have continued to draw thousands every year, as does its version of Pamplona’s Running of the Bulls.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: 'Here Is Where The Action Happens': Meet The People Of Houston
context_meta.summary: Houston was the 24th stop on our Listen To America road trip. We spoke to residents and passers-by to find out what they love (and don’t!) about the city. Here’s what they had to say: “This is a volunteer organization called Second Servings of Houston. ... The whole mission is: ‘fighting hunger, ending waste.’ That’s the mission of the organization. It’s just such an impressive thing.”― Annette Liftman, 56, attorney“I would say Houston is a lot more laid-back [than Dallas]. Definitely more open to diversity as a city. ...

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: 'Why Would You Want To Be Anywhere Else?': Meet The People Of Albuquerque
context_meta.summary: Albuquerque was the 22nd stop on HuffPost’s Listen to America road trip. We spoke to locals about why this New Mexico city is home. Here’s what they had to say: “I’m returning from a stint in LA, New York, around the country really. I’ve come back to my hometown to be able to add to the conversation and share what wealth of knowledge I’ve received living in other cities.”― Jaque Fragua, 31, artist“I live here in Albuquerque by choice. Just closer to my home, I’m originally from here in the Southwest. ...

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: 'I Feel Like The Vibe Is Changing': Meet The People Of Provo, Utah
context_meta.summary: Provo, Utah, was the 20th stop on our Listen to America road trip. We spoke to residents and passersby near the Provo City Library for a day. Here’s what they had to say: “I plan to stay here the rest of my life. We have lots of opportunities here for recreational things.”― Burt Knudson, 79, retired“I flee to here for the strict political persecution from China ... I’m very lucky to flee here and to tell the world what we are facing.”― Rovssel Liu, 20, artist“I decided to move here because I like hiking. ...

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: 'The Sheer Beauty Of Montana Just Intrigues Me': Meet The People Of Livingston
context_meta.summary: Our 19th stop on the Listen To America road trip was Livingston, Montana.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: 13 Asians On Identity And The Struggle Of Loving Their Eyes
context_meta.summary: When we talk about Asian eyes, we talk about slantedness, roundness, smooth monolids and deep eyelid folds. But what we’re also talking about is Westernization, beauty standards and self-acceptance. To talk about Asian eyes is to have a unique lexicon.

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: How Airbnb Is Pushing Locals Out Of New Orleans’ Coolest Neighborhoods
context_meta.summary: About a year ago, a bachelorette party from Texas rented a house through Airbnb on Ursulines Avenue in Treme, a residential neighborhood close to the bars and restaurants of the French Quarter. “My oldest son woke up and there was an inflatable dildo taped to the house next door and I was like, ‘We’re out of here,’” said Christian Rhodes, a 36-year-old lawyer whose clients include the Greater New Orleans Hotel & Lodging Association and Uber. The balloon incident was when Janice Coatney realized her neighborhood had changed.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Artist Transforms Abandoned Buildings In New Orleans With Powerful Art
context_meta.summary: The New Orleans native aims to criticize how the city neglected under-resourced neighborhoods after the 2005 natural disaster ― but also wants to celebrate the residents of these mostly-black neighborhoods and the pride and beauty of their communities. “Think about the spaces, they were in black, poor communities,” Odums told HuffPost. Odums’ “Be” art series began with “Project Be” in 2013.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: New Orleans' School System Has Failed Its Students Post-Katrina
context_meta.summary: The state of education in New Orleans is constantly changing and churning. For children, positive change is always good, of course, but there is a need for constants and plenty of consistency, as well. The search for a quality education in New Orleans has been and remains a chore.

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: To Stop The Cycle Of Poverty, We Need To Invest In Mothers
context_meta.summary: It’s an area where ― although measures are being put in place for some to thrive ― families living in poverty continue to yearn for the basic necessities of life: a quality education, safe communities, affordable housing and the means by which one can attain all three. The Wayfinder Foundation was founded on the principle that if we invest in women, we will change the world. Too often, work requirements for public assistance funnel mothers toward highly feminized industries ― hospitality, retail, low-end health care, etc. ― that pay low wages, offer no sick leave, and have no unemployment benefits.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Meet The Young People Trying To Make Sure Detroit's Rebirth Works For Everybody
context_meta.summary: DETROIT ― Recovery for Detroit was difficult to imagine as recently as a few years ago, when the forced bankruptcy of General Motors and Chrysler ― and then the city government itself ― seemed to provide the epitaph for a collapse roughly half a century in the making. Today Woodward Avenue, the city’s main thoroughfare, is usually full of people ― whether it’s young professionals trekking from their offices to food carts during the day, or hipsters jumping between bars and restaurants at night. A just-opened basketball arena has lured the NBA’s Pistons back from the suburbs, and a new streetcar runs along Woodward, linking the nearby medical center and Wayne State University.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Young DACA Recipients In Houston Take On Hurricane Harvey -- And Trump
context_meta.summary: Days later, the Trump administration ended the Deferred Action for Child Arrivals or DACA program, putting nearly 700,000 young undocumented immigrants at risk of losing their jobs and being deported when their protections expire. For 29-year-old DACA recipient Oscar Hernandez, a lead organizer with the Houston chapter of immigrant rights group United We Dream, it was time to help out. “Here in Houston, we had a lot of folks who lost everything during the hurricane,” Hernandez told HuffPost earlier this month.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: 'Great Community, Great People': Meet The People Of Lincoln
context_meta.summary: Lincoln, Nebraska, was stop No. 17 on our Listen To America road trip. “I’m in Lincoln just to kind of get my feet back on the ground ... I came back to my hometown to start my future and to eventually leave again.

context_meta.author: Yahoo News
context_meta.title: In St. Louis, This Woman Is Making A Change One Meal At A Time
context_meta.summary: This is the second episode in the HuffPost podcast series “I’m Still Here” that visits communities whose tales of adversity have put them on the map and explores what “survival” in America really looks like.

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: 'We're Making Change': Meet The People Of Des Moines
context_meta.summary: Des Moines, Iowa, was the 15th stop on our Listen To America road trip. We hunkered down in the Urban Dreams parking lot to talk to locals about their lives in Iowa. Here’s what they had to say:“I run a nonprofit that connects veterans with resources to help them with the issues that often go along with post-traumatic stress and traumatic brain injuries.”― Lisa Naslund, 52, nonprofit founder “I’m an Iowan. I’m a Midwesterner. I love the values that we share ... I believe we’re making change. ...

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Opiate Addiction Is An Ongoing Crisis In America
context_meta.summary: The vast availability of this medication speaks volumes about the opioid epidemic in America. Opiate dependence is a behavioral health issue and chronic disease that no racial demographic is immune to. Since the year 2000, the availability and consumption of prescription pain medications, heroin and other illicit opiates in America has increased exponentially.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: 'Our Backyard Has Become A Graveyard': Saving Lives On The U.S.-Mexico Border
context_meta.summary: When Leesa Jacobson first moved to this small town on the Arizona border with Mexico, she feared her storefront offices might get firebombed. Jacobson invited him in and soaked his feet before he went on his way.

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Two Months After Hurricane Harvey, Local Dependability Is Still Key
context_meta.summary: During Hurricane Harvey, four feet of fast water coursed through my 81-year-old father’s house, destroying his life’s possessions and the home he’d lived in for 30 years. On local Houston news, when I had a moment to watch, I heard much about “Houston Strong.” It was a catchy phrase and applicable.

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: The Ultimate Odessa, Texas, Road Trip Playlist
context_meta.summary: Spotify has curated playlists reflecting the local flavor of each stop on HuffPost’s “Listen to America” tour using location-based data to find out what people are really listening to in 20-plus cities. Check back for more from Sept. 12 through Oct. 30.

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Despite Death Threats, Former Planned Parenthood Leader Still Fights For Women
context_meta.summary: In the middle of the night, with her house packed with grade school boys sleeping over for her son’s birthday party, Karen Pieper Hildebrand got her first death threat. Hildebrand, 59, was shaken, but decided against calling the police. “Well, that’s the price you pay for doing what you’re doing,” Hildebrand said an officer told her in response to the disturbing threat from the previous night.

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: 'Around Here, You're Either Eating Steak Or You're Eating Beans'
context_meta.summary: Back when just about every oil pump jack in town was running, Tara Smith had more work than she could handle. The West Texas native ran her own company, Dirty Ride Mobile Wash, going out into the oil fields to clean muddy tank trucks. Demand for her services was so high that Smith invested in two additional pickups and a pair of industrial steamers just to keep up.

context_meta.author: Yahoo News
context_meta.title: 2 Dads On The Challenges And Rewards Of Black Fatherhood
context_meta.summary: Welcome to “The Story We Share,” a series of Q&As that profile two people with similar identities ― but who live in very different places.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: 5 Amazing Places To Shop In New Orleans, Louisiana
context_meta.summary: Bourbon Street might be the most well known street in the city, but other areas, including the shopping-friendly Magazine Street, are more than worth exploring. Originally a vintage only store, Trashy Diva has expanded to include its own designs since opening its doors in 1996. According to its website, its inspiration is  “taken from antique and vintage clothing with a strong emphasis on feminine styles that flatter a variety of body types.” Oh, and did we mention they carry sizes 0-24?
